title: De Blasio Vows to End Solitary Confinement in New York City Jails
summary: Four-person working group will draft recommendations to eradicate the practice, which will be voted on this fall. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio pledged Monday to stop using solitary confinement in the city's jail system, marking a victory for criminal-justice reform advocates who have long argued the practice is inhumane.

title: De Blasio Agrees to Cut NYPD Funding by $1 Billion
summary: Police department's annual funding would drop to about $5 billion from $6 billion. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said he had agreed to shift more than $1 billion in annual funding out of the New York Police Department, as he and the city council raced to agree on the city's budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: One Man's Supreme Court
summary: The Chief Justice relies on an abortion precedent he dissented from.. So much for all those crocodile fears about the end of abortion rights. The Supreme Court ruled 5-4 Monday that a state can't even require abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a hospital. And the logic of the concurring opinion from Chief Justice John Roberts, who provided the fifth vote, suggests not even de minimis regulation of abortion will survive his Court's scrutiny.

title: Woke Capital Targets Free Speech
summary: Advertisers want to turn Facebook into a political enforcement tool.. American companies are in a frenzy to get ahead of the current moment of woke moral panic. That sometimes means sacrificing an unlucky employee to the political mob or buying copies of the best-seller "White Fragility" to encourage workers to define themselves by race. Now large firms are joining a campaign to turn social media platforms into tools of political surveillance and enforcement against conservatives.

title: The Court's Missed Opportunity on Consumer Financial Protection
summary: The President can fire the CFPB director but the agency survives.. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is here to stay, Senator Elizabeth Warren declared Monday after a 5-4 Supreme Court majority struck down the agency's independent director for-cause removal provision from the Dodd-Frank Act. While a narrow victory for the separation of powers, the decision otherwise ratifies her constitutional monstrosity.

title: The GOP's Lampoon Vacation
summary: A tax credit for getting away from it all-or merely to the Hamptons.. The fallout from the coronavirus is leading to all sorts of bad ideas from both political parties. Democrats want to spend multiple trillions of dollars on everything while Republicans prefer their subsidizing through the tax code. A bad example of the latter is Senator Martha McSally's proposal for a $4,000 vacation tax credit.

title: A Monument to Our Shared Purpose
summary: The Freedmen's Memorial in Washington embodies not white supremacy, but African-American agency and cooperative struggle.. At the end of the Civil War, on April 11, 1865, Abraham Lincoln gave a speech proposing that, in Louisiana, freed slaves and black Union Army soldiersbe given the right to vote. An enraged white supremacist who was in attendance left promising that he would "put him through." Three nights later, he-the actor John Wilkes Booth-did.

title: Millions of American Homes at Greater Flood Risk Than Government Estimates, New Study Says
summary: Nearly six million properties across the U.S. have a substantial risk of flooding that isn't disclosed by federal flood maps, according to a nonprofit research firm. Nearly six million properties across the U.S. have a substantial risk of flooding that isn't disclosed by federal flood maps, according to a nonprofit research firm that released its own U.S. flood maps Monday.

title: Treasury Bond Yields Stay Near Recent Lows
summary: Yields have declined in recent sessions amid concerns about how mounting coronavirus cases will hit efforts to restart the economy. U.S. government yields clung near recent lows even as stock markets rebounded Monday.

title: Telegram to Pay $18.5 Million to Settle SEC Charges
summary: The regulator accused the cryptocurrency company of violating registration requirements of U.S. securities laws. Telegram Group Inc. and a subsidiary agreed to pay an $18.5 million civil penalty and return about $1.22 billion to investors to settle charges that it violated investor-protection laws, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Supreme Court Orders Restructuring of Consumer-Finance Watchdog
summary: High court rules Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's single-director setup is too independent from president. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court ordered changes to a government consumer-finance watchdog created in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, capping a 10-year battle over the agency by ruling its structure was unconstitutional because the director held too much unchecked power.

title: 'Warrior Nun' Review: Sisters' Acts of Violence
summary: Simon Barry's Netflix series provides a religious twist to gun-blazing superhero adventure.. 'Holy ninjas!" seems like a perfectly reasonable response to "Warrior Nun." How many superhero adventure series feature black-clad cloistered women and automatic weapons? Religious miracles and foul, flaming demons? High-tech hokum and a millennium's worth of cooked-up Christian history? Resurrection and recoil?

title: Capitalism After the Coronavirus
summary: The pandemic provides an opportunity to build a resilient, healthy, fair and zero-carbon economy.. We wrote an op-ed for these pages in 2006 titled "For People and Planet," in which we argued for a long-term, sustainable, multistakeholder approach to business. We said America's corporate leaders should put environmental, social and governance factors at the heart of their decision-making.

title: A Radio Trick for TV Sports: Make Stuff Up
summary: Fake crowd noise is nothing compared with how games were called in the 1950s.. 'Robinson knocks the dirt out of his cleats. He looks to the third-base coach for the sign. Pee Wee leads off first. Crowd's getting edgy. And here's the pitch from Brecheen. Robbie swings, and smacks a hard . . ."

title: Speak Up, Mr. Biden
summary: As mobs tear down statues of Lincoln and Grant, where does the Democrat stand?. How America's political class must pine for the halcyon days of just a few weeks ago, when only statues of Confederate generals (and the occasional Christopher Columbus) had to fear being pulled down or defaced. Save for scattered notes of disapproval from historians, life largely went on.

title: 'The Brothers York' Review: A Hazardous Fraternity
summary: Shakespeare gives us a portrait of dynastic rivalry involving treachery, cruelty and vaulting ambition. The real story is no less dramatic.. For years, the Tudors have dominated English history for the common reader, and, thanks to Hilary Mantel, the author of a popular trilogy that began with "Wolf Hall," they dominate historical fiction too. Thomas Penn has already written a biography of the first Tudor monarch, Henry VII. Now he has stepped back to the Wars of the Roses, covered by Shakespeare in the three parts of "Henry VI" and in "Richard III." The House of York is his subject, the losing side of a struggle for dynastic supremacy that ultimately put the Tudors in power.

title: The Global Political Pandemic
summary: 'Democratic decline syndrome' began to hit years before the novel coronavirus.. Two pandemics are sweeping the planet, and so far nobody has found a cure for either. There's Covid-19 and there's a global democracy blight causing political life in many countries to become more polarized and less democratic.

title: Notable & Quotable: American Academy of Pediatrics
summary: 'The AAP strongly advocates that all policy considerations for the coming school year should start with a goal of having students physically present in school.'. From "COVID-19 Planning Considerations: Guidance for School Re-entry" from the American Academy of Pediatrics, June 25:

title: Reddit Bans The_Donald, a Popular Forum for Trump Supporters
summary: Twitch, another online platform, suspends president's streaming account, citing content. The online platforms Reddit Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. -owned Twitch suspended channels used by President Trump and his supporters, saying content there violated the companies' policies, widening a clampdown by social media sites that has fueled a backlash from the White House and its defenders.

title: Chesapeake Energy to Start Tapping $925 Million Bankruptcy Loan
summary: Accessing the chapter 11 loan marks a crucial step in the oil-and-gas company's quest to eliminate $7 billion in debt. Chesapeake Energy Corp. has been cleared to begin drawing on a $925 million bankruptcy loan, a crucial first step in the oil-and-gas producer's plan to eliminate billions of dollars of debt from its balance sheet in chapter 11.

title: Where Advertisers Boycotting Facebook Are Spending Their Money Instead
summary: Marketers' plans include Gmail promotions, more influencer marketing and first-time TikTok buys. Facebook Inc.'s sprawling reach among consumers and its powerful ad targeting abilities have made it a seeming must-buy for many marketers.

title: Gunmen Attack Pakistan Stock Exchange, Citing Its Link to China
summary: Shootout leaves the four attackers dead; separatists from Pakistan province of Balochistan accuse China of economic exploitation of their homeland. ISLAMABAD-The Pakistan Stock Exchange building in Karachi came under attack Monday by an insurgent group saying it targeted the exchange because it is partly owned by a Chinese consortium.

title: Wells Fargo to Cut Dividend; Other Big Banks Hold Steady
summary: Nation's fourth-largest bank has cited weak earnings during the pandemic. Wells Fargo & Co. said it expects to cut its dividend for the first time in more than a decade to preserve capital to weather the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Man, 20, Shot Dead Outside Fla. Amazon Warehouse
summary: The man who was fatally shot was waiting in line to apply for a job, authorities said. A targeted shooting outside an Amazon facility in Jacksonville, Florida, left one person killed and two others slightly wounded Monday, authorities said.

title: Cirque du Soleil Files for Bankruptcy Protection in Canada
summary: Investment firms TPG, Fosun International and Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec have submitted a proposal to buy the circus company's assets. TORONTO-Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada on Monday, in an effort to salvage a circus business that's ground to a halt because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Germany Moves to Overhaul Accounting Oversight Amid Wirecard Scandal
summary: The Federal Ministry of Justice canceled the existing regulator's contract beyond 2021. Germany is overhauling its framework for accounting oversight following a financial scandal at Wirecard AG and is canceling the existing regulator's contract after 2021.

title: New York City May Delay Indoor Dining Amid Coronavirus Surges in Many States
summary: Indoor dining was scheduled for Monday; New Jersey postpones plans indefinitely. New York state and city officials said Monday they may delay the planned reopening of New York City restaurants for indoor dining, extending a shutdown that has already pushed some eateries to the brink of ruin.

title: Coty to Buy Stake in Kim Kardashian West's Makeup Brand
summary: Coty will pay $200 million for 20% stake in KKW, following Coty's deal with Kylie Jenner. Coty Inc. said it is buying a fifth of Kim Kardashian West's makeup brand KKW Holdings LLC for $200 million, wagering that the reality star's reach can boost the company's direct-to-consumer beauty brands.

title: Americans Craving Contact Ponder New Rules for Throwing a Party in Real Life
summary: Trying to celebrate events and minimize risks, people are struggling with ways to host social events; 'The hard part was not hugging anybody'. Throwing a party--a real, in-person party--during a pandemic means pondering questions rarely covered in books of etiquette.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise to Start the Week
summary: Nasdaq, S&P 500 also rise despite coronavirus infections moving higher in southern U.S. states. U.S. stocks climbed Monday as investors weighed the rise in coronavirus infections and the likelihood of future lockdowns against hopes for more stimulus from central banks.

title: The Fashion Industry Is Very White. These Three Designers Know That All Too Well.
summary: Independent Black designers face systemic racism in an industry where they're the clear minority. OVER THE PAST few weeks, as a racial-justice movement has swelled across the U.S., the upper reaches of the fashion industry are being scrutinized. Why are there so few Black designers at luxury labels? Why so few Black editors at glossy fashion publications? And why such a dearth of Black executives in the boardrooms of fashion companies? Less discussed but no less important are the challenges that independent designers of color face at the less glitzy rungs of the ladder.

title: Judge Sets Trial Date for Four Officers Charged in George Floyd Killing
summary: Tentative date is March 8, preceded by crucial hearings in September. MINNEAPOLIS-A Hennepin County judge on Monday set a tentative trial date of March 8 for the four former police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, and warned that any continued statements by public officials on the matter could force a change of venue.

title: MongoDB's Incoming CTO Targets Data Scientists
summary: Mark Porter wants to expand database service's reach beyond software developers. MongoDB Inc. said Monday it has appointed Mark Porter as chief technology officer, as the database service for software developers anticipates growth amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Fed Chairman Says Economy Faces 'New Challenges' from Virus
summary: Fed's Powell says sooner-than-expected reopening has brought 'an important new phase' for the economy. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the reopening of the U.S. economy-and the accompanying upturn in spending and hiring this spring-has happened sooner than central bank officials expected.

title: Protesters Camped Outside City Hall Push for Cuts to NYPD
summary: Mayor de Blasio says he is willing to shift $1 billion from the $6 billion police budget to other city agencies. Hundreds of protesters are camping outside City Hall in lower Manhattan to press for cuts to the New York Police Department's budget, part of a nationwide movement calling for drastic overhauls of local police forces.

title: World Leaders Reboot Face-to-Face Diplomacy
summary: Four months of virtual meetings saved time and money but officials say the personal touch is needed for successful diplomacy. After months of virtual interactions, world leaders are cautiously restarting face-to-face meetings amid growing frustration at the limits of remote diplomacy.

title: AMC Delays Reopening Theaters to Late July
summary: Shift follows changes in release dates for Disney's 'Mulan' and Warner Bros.' 'Tenet'. AMC Entertainment Holdings , the country's largest theater chain, is postponing plans to reopen its U.S. locations by about two weeks, to July 30, following date changes for the upcoming releases of two major films.

title: Battery Metal Lithium Left Behind as Commodities Rebound
summary: Stimulus packages that promote electric-vehicle sales will lead to higher lithium prices in the coming years, analysts said. As oil, copper and other commodities rebound from their coronavirus slump, a metal that powers electric vehicles has been left in the dust. That could change, as lithium is poised to benefit from stimulus packages that aim to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.

title: How to Train to Be a Covid-19 Contact Tracer
summary: Our reporter enrolled in the popular Johns Hopkins contact tracing course. Here's what she learned. As businesses across the country gradually reopen, the ability to do so safely will rely on monitoring people's interactions. Contact tracing - the process of identifying and communicating with anyone who might have come into contact with someone who has tested positive - is being promoted as a key tactic for curbing the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Empower Retirement to Buy Personal Capital
summary: Retirement-plan record-keeper looks to grow in retail advice and wealth management. Empower Retirement said it is buying the personal-wealth management company Personal Capital Corp. for as much as $1 billion, in a move to expand Empower's financial-planning tools to individuals.

title: Fed's Daly Calls Economic Outlook 'Uncertain'
summary: Central banker says it is too soon to determine if some regions are reopening too quickly in pandemic. Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco leader Mary Daly declined to say Monday whether an uptick in coronavirus-related illness in parts of the country is on track to damage her expectations of a slow and gradual recovery.

title: Q&A: What Does the Russia Vote Mean for Putin?
summary: The result of vote isn't in much doubt, but the outcome could mean far-reaching changes for Russia as he lays plans to prolong his reign. MOSCOW-Russians are casting their ballots in a vote that is expected to pave the way for President Vladimir Putin, in power for more than two decades, to remain in charge until 2036.

title: The Supreme Court on Sex, Gender and Jobs
summary: If people are now to be defined as male or female based only on self-identification, why should we continue to make distinctions based on traditional, antiquated notions about gender?. Regarding David Crawford and Michael Hanby's "The Abolition of Man and Woman" (op-ed, June 25): If people are now to be defined as male or female based only on self-identification, why should we continue to make distinctions based on traditional, antiquated notions about gender? Let's eliminate Title IX. Schools can have one football, baseball, softball, basketball, etc., team and the best players (no matter their claimed gender identity will play). Same for professional leagues. Let's eliminate all-girls and all-boys schools. After all, who is to say which is which?

title: North Korea Responding to Financial Dearth
summary: What has likely prompted Kim Jong Un to "hit the pause button" regarding his threats against South Korea isn't a desire to place North-South reconciliation back on track but financial desperation.. What has likely prompted Kim Jong Un to "hit the pause button" regarding his threats against South Korea isn't a desire to place North-South reconciliation back on track but financial desperation ("Kim Pauses Threats Against South," World News, June 25). International sanctions have hurt. But the sealing of the Chinese and Russian borders for the past several months to stop the spread of coronavirus has deprived the North Korean economy of almost all foreign-exchange inflows, pushing its public finances to the edge. North Korea has no access to external financing that would cushion such an austerity shock.

title: BP Exits Petrochemicals Business in $5 Billion Deal
summary: The sale comes as the energy giant's peers expand their chemical operations. LONDON-Energy giant BP PLC has agreed to sell its petrochemicals business to a British chemicals company for $5 billion, marking the largest deal by an oil major since the coronavirus outbreak gripped the global economy.

title: ESG Is Risk Management, Not an Asset Class
summary: ESG isn't an asset class, but rather prudent risk management. It applies to all funds across all asset classes across investment processes.. Regarding Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia's "Retirees' Security Trumps Other Social Goals" (op-ed, June 24): All major U.S. asset managers consider the material risks posed by environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors to their investments, because ESG integration is a necessary part of effective risk management.

title: Seattle City Council's Power Grab Should Scare Voters
summary: Seattle's voters really need to think hard about where they are heading.. Regarding F. Vincent Vernuccio and Michael Saltsman's "Welcome to The 'Hotel Seattle'" (op-ed, June 23): Seattle's City Council's efforts to impose its will on private businesses by ordering them to raise incomes arbitrarily and not leave the city, even if they become unprofitable, is more evidence that so-called liberal progressivism is either laughably incompetent or dangerously authoritarian. Either way, the council's view that local government should control the private sector from the "commanding heights" is banana-republic socialism by any other name. Seattle's voters really need to think hard about where they are heading.

title: Russia Reinforces Foothold in Libya as Militia Leader Retreats
summary: Moscow delivers more support to warlord Khalifa Haftar while talking with other key players in divided country. LONDON-Russia is sending reinforcements to Libya to help military leader Khalifa Haftar, who is on the defensive after a failed effort to topple the country's United Nations-backed government, as Moscow seeks to shape the fate of the nation and its vast oil reserves.

title: Younger People are Hit Harder by Covid-19 in Countries with Fewer Resources
summary: Populations in poorer countries are more likely to develop health problems at an earlier age. In places like India and Mexico, people in their 50s and 60s who are infected with Covid-19, are more likely to die than those in a similar age group in the U.S. or Europe. Nearly half of Covid deaths in Mexico are people between the ages of 45 and 65, and just 17% of the victims have been older than 75. In India, just 12% of Covid deaths have been in people over 75. The reasons more middle-aged people are dying in poorer countries include demographics, a greater prevalence of underlying diseases like diabetes, and weaker health-care systems.

title: Fed Opens Lending Program for New Issuance of Corporate Debt
summary: Effort is part of emergency programs the Fed is running to backstop lending markets reeling from coronavirus. The Federal Reserve formally opened Monday its $500 billion lending program to support issuance of new debt by large corporations, the last of nine emergency programs it is running to backstop lending markets reeling from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: KOTA the Friend Loves 'Ramy,' Jay Z and Hanging in the Park
summary: The rapper and producer has turned down hundreds of thousands of dollars to stay independent. Take a Break With is a recurring feature in which we ask people to tell us what they're into.

title: Portrait of a Pandemic
summary: How the coronavirus rippled through eight young lives.. During the first two months of 2020, Herine Baron was in a pretty constant state of bliss, driving around Miami accompanied by the pulsating rhythms of Caribbean party music. A new mother at 28, she was enjoying her chubby-cheeked baby, Malcolm, and making plans to build a house. As she returned from maternity leave to her hospital nursing job, she had only one big question hanging over her: should she continue her education with an eye toward administration or more advanced nursing?

title: How to Get a Big Break on the Cost of College: Just Ask
summary: The pandemic has accelerated a yearslong shift in financial power toward families, away from schools. The coronavirus pandemic has accelerated a yearslong shift in bargaining power away from colleges and toward families, which are quite prepared to treat tuition as they would a car's price: something to haggle over.

title: Iran Issues Warrant to Arrest Trump Over Killing of General
summary: Interpol was asked for assistance in detaining President Trump, 35 others over the killing of Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani. Iran issued a warrant to arrest President Trump and 35 others over the killing of a top Iranian general earlier this year, a largely symbolic order that is Tehran's latest attempt to draw international attention to what it has labeled an act of terrorism.

title: Governments Roll Back Coronavirus Trade Barriers
summary: More than one-third of export bans on medical gear and other restrictions have been repealed, WTO says. Governments around the world have already repealed more than a third of the export bans on medical products and other restrictions put in place as a response to the coronavirus, the World Trade Organization said Monday.

title: Single-Use Plastic Is Back in the Pandemic Era
summary: Demand for plastic bags, wraps and other hard-to-recycle items has surged amid worries about Covid-19. The world's reopening from coronavirus lockdowns is wrapped in plastic, most of which will never be recycled.

title: Military Gears Up to Fight Racial Bias, a Longstanding Adversary
summary: Black service members face obstacles in trying to reach the top-and even when they get there. The U.S. government has tried at least six times since World War II to root out discrimination and racial bias in the military, through commissions, recommendations and initiatives. Each effort ended in failure, leaving today's military a reflection of society's inequality.

title: Former French Prime Minister Sentenced to Prison on Corruption Charges
summary: Court finds François Fillon misused public funds in employing his wife and two children as aides while he served in Parliament. PARIS-A French court convicted former Prime Minister François Fillonon corruption charges Monday and handed a five-year prison sentence to a politician once considered the front-runner to win France's 2017 presidential election.

title: Facebook's Politics Aren't Aging Well
summary: The most popular social-media app may be living its most unpopular moment. They say it is best not to talk politics among friends. But in trying to avoid the conversation, Facebook has stepped right into the thick of it. Now, some of its most valuable relationships are at risk.

title: Joe Biden Leads; He Still Faces Four Big Tasks
summary: Democratic candidate needs comprehensive economic plan, China strategy, strong debates and the right running mate. For Joe Biden, the immortal words of baseball pitcher and all-purpose sage Satchel Paige apply right now: "Don't look back. Something might be gaining on you."

title: America Needs Leadership on Prescription Prices
summary: Democrats walked away from negotiations, and too many Republicans are sitting on their hands.. Many issues that were top of mind only a few months ago have been sidelined by the coronavirus pandemic, its economic fallout, and social unrest related to police brutality and racial inequality. As a co-author of bipartisan legislation to reduce prescription drug prices, I can tell you that receding media attention is doing the American people a disservice. Congress must not let events serve as an excuse for doing nothing about drug prices. This is the time to address the crisis of health-care affordability.

title: Will Unions Let Schools Reopen?
summary: Emboldened by successful strikes in 2018 and 2019, they may attempt to hold the economy hostage.. Teachers unions know how to play hardball. Last year saw teachers strike across the country, from Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif., to Denver and West Virginia. This year, amid the coronavirus pandemic, leaders of the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers have signaled that they would consider strikes if schools reopen without sufficient safety protections.

title: Colleges Brace for Potential Increased Need for Mental Health Services
summary: With online and in-person teaching planned, counseling teams struggle with uncertainty; a sharper focus on the needs of students of color. As colleges prepare for a school year unlike any other-will classes be in person or online? How can students stay safe in dorms?-their counseling centers are bracing for a wave of student mental health issues.

title: Blemishes Become Equal-Opportunity Offender
summary: Men like to look beautiful, too, and CVS Health is here to help. Need to get gussied up for a Zoom meeting, gentlemen? CVS Health has got you.

title: Second Man Killed in Seattle's 'Occupied' Protest Zone
summary: Police say shooting happened before dawn in city's Capitol Hill area; another man wounded. SEATTLE-One man was killed and another wounded early Monday in Seattle's "occupied" protest zone-the second deadly shooting in the area.

title: South Korea Caught in Endless Coronavirus Whack-a-Mole
summary: Resume Subscription. INCHEON, South Korea-Though South Korea saw infections peak months ago, Hanaram Jang, a 33-year-old contact tracer in this Seoul suburb, has never been busier.

title: Deals Resume in Sale of Risky Loan Funds
summary: Sales of new collateralized-loan obligations hit their fastest pace in early June since pandemic shutdowns began. One of the hardest-hit corners of the global debt markets is showing signs of revival after being virtually shut down by the coronavirus. Sales of new collateralized-loan obligations, or CLOs, have rebounded sharply over the past six weeks as debt investors resume their reach for higher-yielding, riskier debt.

title: Amazon to Pay $500 Million in Bonuses for Front-Line Workers
summary: Payout comes after e-commerce giant ended a short-term pay bump; sales have shot up during coronavirus. Amazon . com Inc. said it would spend more than $500 million on bonuses for employees and some contractors, following months of strong demand from consumers stuck at home during coronavirus lockdowns and pressure on workers handling the jump in orders.

title: Indie Movies Get Chance to Star at Drive-Ins
summary: The coronavirus created openings for low-budget horror movies and thrillers to flourish at old-school venues; 'This would never have happened if things were normal'. It's like a science fiction tale set in the movie business: A pandemic shuts down multiplexes and wipes Hollywood's releases off the calendar. Drive-in theaters rise from obscurity and re-embrace their B-movie heritage. Unsuspecting indie filmmakers rule the box office charts.

title: NBC Lands U.S. Golf Association Rights as Fox Walks Away From Deal
summary: Fox's agreement with the USGA still had several years left to run. The media rights to the United States Golf Association, which include the U.S. Open tournament, are jumping from Fox Sports to NBC Sports, the companies said Monday.

title: Macron Pledges Billions to Make France Greener
summary: French president, whose party failed to win a large city, faces pressure over climate change. PARIS-French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday pledged an additional €15 billion ($16.8 billion) in government spending to help the transition to a cleaner economy, a day after his party took a drubbing at the hands of the Green Party in local elections.

title: Gilead Is Wise to Leave Remdesivir Money on the Table
summary: Gilead could have commanded a higher price for its Covid-19 treatment, but investors should be happy to see restraint. Gilead Sciences is choosing not to maximize profits on its antiviral Covid-19 treatment remdesivir. Its shareholders, not to mention the rest of the drug industry, should be grateful.

title: Blackstone Sees Film-Production Facilities as a Hot New Real-Estate Play
summary: The company wants to own the places where Amazon, Apple and others are making content. Real-estate investors at Blackstone Group Inc. are getting into show business.

title: Rapper Saweetie Thinks You're 'Crazy' if You Don't Wear a Mask
summary: The 26-year-old 'Tap In' star says: 'The fact that some people's priority is to stop wearing masks shows you that a lot of work needs to be done.'. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Warehouses Offer Crowded Shelter in Retail Storm
summary: E-commerce boom will benefit owners of logistics properties, but competition for assets is growing. E-commerce is surging as wary consumers avoid crowded public places. While the likes of Amazon and Europe's top fashion website Zalando are the obvious winners, investors seem just as excited about their warehouse suppliers.

title: South Korea Accuses Japan of Shamelessness in Dispute Over G-7
summary: Squabbles between the U.S. allies multiply, frustrating Washington. Troubled relations between Japan and South Korea have a new point of tension: participation in the Group of Seven club of rich nations.

title: Tennis Takes a 'Leap of Faith' to Jump-Start Season
summary: The complexities of travel and players' health and fitness are among the obstacles to getting back on the court. If all goes according to plan, tennis should stir back to life in mid-August within the groovy confines of an airport hotel that looks like the set of "Mad Men."

title: Patriots Sign Cam Newton-and Get Punished for Allegedly Spying, Again
summary: New England reached a deal with the former MVP quarterback to fill a void left by Tom Brady's departure. The team was also docked a draft pick and fined $1 million for another video scandal.. The New England Patriots were punished, again, for alleged spying. They also signed one of the most potentially lethal quarterbacks in football.

title: Camden Spinout Catalio Sets Up as Biomedical Investor
summary: Investors in Camden Partners' Nexus venture funds supported spinout, transfer of Nexus funds to Catalio. A majority of investors in the Nexus funds of Camden Partners supported the spinout this month of its Nexus Management group into a new firm, Catalio Capital, according to people familiar with the situation.

title: Aircraft Carrier Size Investment Banks Won't Solve China's Financial Woes
summary: A state-owned JPMorgan equivalent might help stave off foreign competition, but it won't do much to fix the sector's structural frailties. China may welcome its own diversified financial powerhouses soon. Size and breadth, however, probably won't be enough to solve the structural contradictions that have long plagued Chinese capital markets.

title: Brexit Is a Test of De-Globalization in a World of Covid-19
summary: At stake in negotiations: how many new barriers to trade to erect between the U.K., Europe. The impending economic divorce between the U.K. and the European Union has become an experiment in rapid de-globalization against the background of a global pandemic.

title: U.S. Allies Capture China Tech Business Despite Washington's Curbs
summary: Huawei procures 5G telecommunications gear from Japan as Beijing pushes for global edge. TOKYO-The U.S. is making it tougher for American companies to help China roll out superfast cellular networks. But companies in Japan, a U.S. ally, are fueling China's leap ahead and making money doing it.

title: Shift Plans to Go Public This Year as Covid-19 Boosts Online Car Sales
summary: Shares of Carvana and Vroom soared with temporary closing of bricks-and-mortar dealerships. Online used-car seller Shift Technologies Inc. plans to go public in the third quarter, looking to ride the momentum of rivals Carvana Co. and Vroom Inc., whose valuations have jumped as the pandemic propels them past traditional dealers.

title: Money-Market Shifts Are Bad News for Profit-Starved Global Banks
summary: Fidelity's closure of some prime money-market funds is a negative omen for non-U.S. banks. Last week, Fidelity Investments said it would close two institutional prime money-market funds with a total of around $14 billion in net assets. That's an ominous portent for some non-U.S. banks, which have increasingly come to rely on such funds to raise dollars they can't easily acquire at home.

title: Coffee's for Closers: How a Short Seller's Warning Helped Take Down Luckin Coffee
summary: 'A new generation of Chinese Fraud 2.0 has emerged,' the report said. In January, days after the shares of Luckin Coffee Inc. hit a record high on the Nasdaq Stock Market , giving the company a $12 billion valuation, a cryptic email arrived in the inboxes of multiple short sellers.

title: Eric Trump Steers Family Empire Under Father's Close Watch
summary: The president's third child is eyeing international expansion after Donald Trump leaves office; 'Eric is the money guy'. On March 17, Eric Trump received word from the Nevada governor's office that he had 24 hours to shut the Las Vegas hotel operated by the family business. Within days, most of the Trump Organization's other properties would also be effectively closed due to the coronavirus pandemic, leaving the 36-year-old son of the president facing one of the company's biggest crises in decades.

title: U.S. Is Vulnerable to China's Dominance in Rare Earths, Report Finds
summary: The metals are used for a variety of advanced technologies, including weapons and computer screens. China sees its dominance in strategic rare-earth minerals as leverage that can be used against the West-including in trade disputes with the U.S., according to a new report by U.S.-based researchers.

title: Banks Have No Idea Who's Creditworthy Anymore
summary: Bankers are tightening lending standards and looking for new data that can help them figure out who's risky and who's not. Banks have pulled back sharply on lending to U.S. consumers during the coronavirus crisis. One reason: They can't tell who is creditworthy anymore.

title: Families Persist With U.S. Adoptions Amid Pandemic
summary: Resume Subscription. When Eric Emch and his husband Alan Lane began trying to adopt a baby two years ago, they didn't count on a pandemic. In March, they were hunkered down at home in New York City when they learned they had been matched with a girl due in May.

title: Masks Could Help Stop Coronavirus. So Why Are They Still Controversial?
summary: Confusing government advice at the start of the pandemic and cultural misgivings may have limited acceptance. As countries begin to reopen their economies, face masks, an essential tool for slowing the spread of coronavirus, are struggling to gain acceptance in the West. One culprit: Governments and their scientific advisers.

title: Covid-19 Drug Remdesivir to Cost $3,120 for Typical Patient
summary: Gilead Sciences, remdesivir's maker, said its price will depend on who is paying and how long a patient takes the drug. Gilead Sciences Inc. detailed its pricing plans for Covid-19 drug remdesivir, saying it will charge U.S. hospitals $3,120 for a typical patient.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Says U.S. Intelligence Didn't Find Russian Bounty Information Credible
summary: The president said in a late-night Twitter post that he wasn't briefed about the information because of that conclusion. President Trump said late Sunday that intelligence officials told him they didn't find information about Russians offering a bounty to Afghan militants who attacked U.S. troops sufficiently credible to brief him or Vice President Mike Pence.

title: Louisville Police Arrest Suspect in Fatal Shooting at Breonna Taylor Protest
summary: Protesters against police violence and racial injustice have been occupying Jefferson Square Park for weeks. Louisville police have arrested a Kentucky man in his early 20s in connection with a fatal shooting Saturday night in a park where people have been gathering to protest police violence.
